See also: långsam

German[edit]

Etymology[edit]

From Middle High German lancsam, from Old High German lancsam, from Proto-Germanic *langasamaz (“lengthy, long-lasting”), equivalent to lang +‎ -sam. Compare dialectical British English longsome (“tedious, protracted”).

Pronunciation[edit]

  • IPA(key): /ˈlaŋzaːm/
  • (Germany)
    		(file)
  • (Austria)
    		(file)

Adjective[edit]

langsam (comparative langsamer, superlative am langsamsten)

  1. slow (taking a long time to move or travel; not happening in a short time)
    Das Projekt geht nur langsam voran.

Antonyms[edit]

  • schnell

Derived terms[edit]

  • Langsamkeit

Adverb[edit]

langsam

  1. slowly (at a slow pace)
    Das Auto fährt langsam.

Antonyms[edit]

  • schnell

Further reading[edit]

  • langsam in Duden online

German Low German[edit]

Etymology[edit]

Cognate to German langsam, Dutch langzaam, English longsome.

Adjective[edit]

langsam (comparative langsamer, superlative langsamst)

  1. slow

Declension[edit]

Indonesian[edit]

Etymology[edit]

From Dutch langzaam, from lancsom, lancsaem, from Old Dutch *langsam, from Proto-Germanic *langasamaz (“lengthy, long-lasting”). Compare English longsome, German langsam.

Pronunciation[edit]

  • IPA(key): /laŋ.sam/
  • Hyphenation: lang‧sam

Adjective[edit]

langsam

  1. (colloquial) longsome, slow

Further reading[edit]

  • “langsam” in Kamus Besar Bahasa Indonesia (KBBI) Daring, Jakarta: Badan Pengembangan dan Pembinaan Bahasa, Kementerian Pendidikan dan Kebudayaan Republik Indonesia, 2016.

Norwegian Nynorsk[edit]

Etymology[edit]

From German langsam

Pronunciation[edit]

  • IPA(key): /²lɑŋsɑm/

Adjective[edit]

langsam (masculine and feminine langsam, neuter langsamt, definite singular and plural langsame, comparative langsamare, indefinite superlative langsamast, definite superlative langsamaste)

  1. slow

References[edit]

  • “langsam” in The Nynorsk Dictionary.
